title: Interval for slope of tree height and diameter

content.description:
Measuring the height of a tree is usually more difficult than measuring the diameter of the tree. Therefore, many researchers use regression models to predict the height of a tree from its diameter measured at <math alttext="4" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mn>4</mn> </mrow> </mstyle> </math> feet <math alttext="6" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>6</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> inches from the ground. The following computer output shows the results of a linear regression based on the heights, in feet, and the diameters, in inches, recorded from <math alttext="31" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>31</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> felled trees.

Estimate
 Std Error
 <math alttext="t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> value
 Pr(<math alttext="greater than the absolute value of t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>></mo><mrow><mo>|</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>|</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>)

Intercept

 <math alttext="4.383" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>4.383</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="14.15" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>14.15</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="0.0000" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.0000</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

Diameter

content.question: Which of the following is a <math alttext="95" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mn>95</mn> </mrow> </mstyle> </math> percent confidence interval for the slope of the population regression line?

topic.text: 9.2: Confidence Intervals for the Slope of a Regression Model

skill.text: Skill 3.D: Construct a confidence interval, provided conditions for inference are met.
